course1.prereq: 3521 or 5521, and 2501 or Phil 1338, and CSE 3901 or 3902 or 3903, and 2nd writing; or grad standing.
course1.name: Capstone Design: Knowledge-Based Systems
course1.desc: Capstone design project; conceptual and technical design; theory and practice of knowledge-based systems; teamwork, written and oral communication skills.

course2.prereq: 3231 or 5231, and 2501 or Philos 1338, and CSE3901 or 3902 or 3903, and 2nd writing course or grad standing.
course2.topic: SWE methodology selection, High-level project, teamwork
course2.name: Capstone Design: Software Applications
course2.desc: Capstone design project: application of software engineering techniques, methodologies and technologies in software lifecycle activities using enterprise software frameworks; teamwork, written and oral communication.

course3.prereq: 3541 or 5541, and 2501 or Philos 1338, and CSE 3901 or 3902 or 3903, and second writing course; or Grad standing.
course3.topic: SWE for games, game idea generation, High-level project
course3.name: Capstone Design: Game Design and Development
course3.desc: Capstone design project; conceptual and technical design and implementation of interactive game, integrating custom code and toolkits; teamwork, written and oral communication skills.

course4.prereq: 3541 or 5541, and 2501 or Philos 1338, and CSE 3901 or 3902 or 3903, and second writing course; or Grad standing
course4.name: Capstone Design: Computer Animation
course4.desc: Capstone design project: conceptual and technical design and implementation of computer animation incorporating animation elements; teamwork, written and oral communication skills.

course5.prereq: 3241 or 5241, and 2501 or Philos 1338, and CSE 3901 or 3902 or 3903, and second writing course; or Grad standing
course5.topic: Web-based Information Systems, multimedia and scientific data management
course5.name: Capstone Design: Information Systems
course5.desc: Capstone design project; information system principles: database design methods and tools, indexing, searching, application development, testing, evaluation; teamwork, written and oral communication skills.

course6.prereq: 2501 or Philos 1338, and CSE 3901 or 3902 or 3903, and second writing course; or Grad standing
course6.topic: The scientific method, theory-guided data science, the data science life-cycle,  data analysis
course6.name: Capstone Design: Research-Focused Projects
course6.desc: Capstone design project; convergent and scalable research formulation and development, computational solutions to open-ended research problems, teamwork, written and oral communication skills.

course7.prereq: 2331 or 5331, or Grad standing. Not open to students with credit for 3521
course7.name: Survey of Artificial Intelligence I: Basic Techniques
course7.desc: Survey of the basic concepts and techniques in artificial Intelligence, including problem solving, knowledge representation, and machine learning.

course8.prereq: 3521 or 5521, and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, or Data Analytics major; or Grad standing.
course8.topic: Probability theory, Bayesian networks and probabilistic representations, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Diagrammatic reasoning and abductive inference, Computer vision
course8.name: Survey of Artificial Intelligence II: Advanced Techniques
course8.desc: Survey of advanced concepts, techniques, and applications of artificial intelligence, including knowledge representation, learning, natural language understanding, and vision.

course9.prereq: 3521, 5521, or 5243; and 5522, Stat 3460, or 3470; and Math 2568, 2174, 4568, or 5520H; or Grad standing.
course9.topic: Basics of statistical pattern recognition, Probability and statistical inference, Bayes decision theory, Analysis of statistical algorithms, Clustering, Spectral clustering
course9.name: Machine Learning and Statistical Pattern Recognition
course9.desc: Introduction to basic concepts of machine learning and statistical pattern recognition; techniques for classification, clustering and data representation and their theoretical analysis.

course10.prereq: 2331, or Sr or Grad standing. Not open to students with credit for 634.
course10.topic: Introductory computer vision, Image formation, Noise removal, Edge detection, Pyramids, Region segmentation, 2-D shape, Template matching, Motion, Tracking, 3-D, Event analysis, Features, Motion capture
course10.name: Computer Vision for Human-Computer Interaction
course10.desc: Computer vision algorithms for use in human-computer interactive systems; image formation, image features, segmentation, shape analysis, object tracking, motion calculation, and applications.

course11.prereq: (CSE 3521 or CSE 5521) and (CSE 5522 or Stat 3460 or Stat 3470)
course11.name: Foundations of Speech and Language Processing
course11.desc: Fundamentals of natural language processing, automatic speech recognition and speech synthesis; lab projects concentrating on building systems to process written and/or spoken language.

course12.prereq: 3521 or 5521. Not open to students with credit for 779
course12.topic: Introduction and McCulloch-Pitts networks, Perceptrons, Regression and least mean square algorithm, Multilayer perceptrons, Radial-basis function networks, Support vector machines, Recurrent networks, Unsupervised learning and self-organization,
course12.name: Introduction to Neural Networks
course12.desc: Survey of fundamental methods and techniques of neural networks; single- and multi-layer perceptrons; radial-basis function networks; support vector machines; recurrent networks; supervised and unsupervised learning.

course13.prereq: 2421, or 2451 and ECE 2560; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, Data Analytics, or ECE majors.
course13.name: Systems II: Introduction to Operating Systems
course13.desc: Introduction to operating system concepts: process, CPU scheduling, memory management, file system and storage, and multi-threaded programming.

course14.prereq: 1212, 1221, 1222, 1223, 1224, Engr 1221, 1281.01H, 1281.02H, or CSE Placement Level A. Prereq or concur: Math 1151, 1161.01, or 1161.02. Not open to students with credit for 5022.
course14.name: Software I: Software Components
course14.desc: Intellectual foundations of software engineering; design-by-contract principles; mathematical modeling of software functionality; component-based software from client perspective; layered data representation

course15.prereq: Prereq: 2221. Concur: 2321. Not open to students with credit for 2231.01.
course15.name: Software II: Software Development and Design
course15.desc: Data representation using hashing, search trees, and linked data structures; algorithms for sorting; using trees for language processing; component interface design; best practices in Java.

course16.prereq: 2122, 2123 or 2231; and 2321 or Math 2566; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, Data Analytics or Math majors
course16.name: Systems I: Introduction to Low-Level Programming and computer Organization
course16.desc: Introduction to computer architecture at machine and assembly language level; pointers and addressing; C programming at machine level; computer organization

course17.prereq: Prereq: 2122, 2123, or 2221; and Math 1151, or 1161. Concur (for students with credit for 2221): 2231.
course17.name: Foundations I: Discrete Structures
course17.desc: Propositional and first-order logic; basic proof techniques; graphs, trees; analysis of algorithms; asymptotic analysis; recurrence relations.

course18.prereq: Prereq: 2231, 2321, and Stat 3460 or 3470. Concur: Math 3345 and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, Data Analytics, Math majors or CIS minor.
course18.name: Foundations II: Data Structures and Algorithms
course18.desc: Design/analysis of algorithms and data structures; divide-and-conquer; sorting and selection, search trees, hashing, graph algorithms, string matching; probabilistic analysis; randomized algorithms; NP-completeness.

course19.prereq: Not open to students with credit for 1111 or 1113
course19.topic: Computers in society; word processing, Application software, The components of the system unit; spreadsheet application, Operating systems and utility programs, input and output devices, Database management; communications and networks
course19.name: Introduction to Computing Technology
course19.desc: A course of general interest giving experience with personal computer software, e.g., word processors and spreadsheets; provides fundamental computer literacy; neither teaches nor requires programming.

course20.prereq: Not open to students with credit for 1112 (105), 1113 (101), or 200. GE quant reason math and logical anly course
course20.name: Introduction to Computer-Assisted Problem Solving
course20.desc: Problem solving techniques using productivity software; spreadsheets, formulas, conditional logic; relational databases, relational algebra; word processing; data presentation; graphics.

course21.prereq: Not open to students with credit for 1111 (101), 1113, 105, or 200.
course21.topic: Computer basics, Excel, simple webpage, powerpoint
course21.name: Introduction to Computer-Assisted Problem Solving for Construction Systems Management
course21.desc: Using productivity software, especially spreadsheets and databases, to solve problems for construction management; relative/absolute cell referencing, logic, functions; relational databases, querying, project integration.

course22.prereq: Math 1130 (130) or above. Not open to students with credit for 1111 (101), 1112 (105), 2111, or 200.
course22.name: Spreadsheet Programming for Business
course22.desc: Spreadsheet modeling/programming concepts and techniques to solve business related problems; efficient/effective data handling, computational analysis and decision support.

course23.prereq: Not open to students with credit for 1111, 1112, or 2111.
course23.topic: Relational database management systems, Table Relationships, Use the query tool to find/organize information, Access Macros, SQL, Forms and Reports
course23.name: Introduction to Databases Using MS Access
course23.desc: Database concepts and techniques for efficient/effective data handling, computational analysis and decision support.

course24.prereq: Not open to students with credit for 203 or 204.
course24.topic: Software installation, and basic concepts, intro to programming with media, images, colors, encodings, Loops, new definitions, simple image manipulations, Nested loops, conditionals, Boolean expressions, advanced image manipulations, Sequencing, iteration, and drawing,
course24.name: Computational Thinking in Context: Images, Animation, and Games
course24.desc: Introduction to computational thinking, focusing on problem solving and programming concepts and skills needed to manipulate digital images and to create interactive graphics, animations, and games; creativity and imagination encouraged.

course25.topic: Basic concepts of video games, Introduction to programming for web-based games, Loops, new definitions, simple controls, Conditionals, Boolean expressions, advanced controls
course25.name: Computational Thinking in Context: Game Development
course25.desc: Introduction to computational thinking, focusing on problem solving and programming concepts and skills needed to develop video games.

course26.prereq: Concur:Math 1151, 1154, or 1161. Not open to students with credit for Engr 1281.01 or 1281.02. This course is available for EM credit.
course26.topic: C++, loop, method, pointer, structure, c++ array, c++ string
course26.name: Introduction to Computer Programming in C++ for Engineers and Scientists
course26.desc: Introduction to computer programming and to problem solving techniques using computer programs with applications in engineering and the physical sciences; algorithm development; programming lab experience.

course27.prereq: Math 1130, 1140, 1149, 1150, or 1151, or Math Placement Level L. This course is available for EM credit.
course27.topic: Basic concepts, Primitive types and expressions; String; basic I/O, Flow of control and Boolean expressions, Defining methods, Arrays, Basic exception handling and standard Java I/O, Classes and objects
course27.name: Introduction to Computer Programming in Java
course27.desc: Introduction to computer programming and to problem solving techniques using computer programs; programming lab experience.

course28.prereq: Math 1130, 1140, 1149, 1150, or 1151, or Math Placement Level L.
course28.topic: Expressions and Types; basic I/O, Lists, Tuples and Dictionaries, Flow of control and Boolean expressions, Defining functions, File I/O, Classes and objects
course28.name: Introduction to Computer Programming in Python
course28.desc: Introduction to computer programming and to problem solving techniques using computer programs; programming lab experience.

course29.prereq: Math 1151 (152) or equivalent, and Physics 1250 (131). Not open to students with credit for 1221 or Engr 1221.
course29.topic: Introduction to modeling; modeling concepts and definitions, Introduction to MATLAB, scripts, MATLAB arrays, array math, MATLAB programming mechanisms, MATLAB i/0, Advanced graphing in MATLAB; curve fitting, Linear models, Nonlinear functions; modeling examples, Stochastic models
course29.name: Introduction to Modeling and Simulation
course29.desc: Concepts of modeling and simulation; develop MATLAB skills to explore modeling concepts; project: design, implementation, verification/validation of model; oral and written project report.

course30.prereq: Math 1130 or above, or Math Placement Level L. Not open to students with credit for 1111 or 1112. This course is available for EM credit. GE quant reason math and logical anly course.
course30.topic: intro to computing, spreadsheet basics, decision making with spreadsheets, financial and date functions, intro to database
course30.name: Modeling and Problem Solving with Spreadsheets and Databases
course30.desc: Spreadsheet and database modeling/programming concepts and techniques to solve business related problems; efficient/effective data handling, computational analysis and decision support. Additional topics: computer concepts, networking, project integration.

course31.prereq: 1222, 1223, 1224, Engr 1281.01H, or 1281.02H. Prereq or concur: Math 1151, 1161.01, or 1161.02. Not open to students with credit for 1111, 1112, 1113, or 2111.
course31.topic: spreadsheet design, Excel Solver, Pivot tables, graphing, programming in Excel VBA, introduction to Database Design, summarizing Data
course31.name: Modeling and Problem Solving with Spreadsheets and Databases for Engineers
course31.desc: Spreadsheet and database modeling/programming concepts and techniques to solve business and engineering related problems; efficient/effective data handling, computational analysis and decision support.

course32.prereq: 1222 (202). Not open to students with credit for 230.
course32.topic: Introduction to course computing environment, Basic features, getting started, basic data types, Advanced data types, functions without returned values, Classes, members, constructors, Friends, destructors, returned values in functions, Operators, Inheritance, Flow of control, dynamic memory allocation, arrays and pointers
course32.name: Data Structures Using C++
course32.desc: Introduction to programming in C++ and object-oriented programming; encapsulation using classes, inheritance, etc.

course33.topic: Object-oriented programming, Recursion, Sorting and binary search, Linked list, Stacks, Queues, Binary trees
course33.name: Data Structures Using Java
course33.desc: Subroutines and modular programming; searching; basic data structures; recursion; introduction to sequential files.

course34.prereq: 2123, and enrollment in Business Info Sys major or CIS minor
course34.topic: Picture clauses; value clauses; group items; literals; Vocabulary; columns; margins; basic coding rules; Identification and environment division; data names;
course34.name: Business Programming with File Processing
course34.desc: Business data processing principles and programming: sequential file processing algorithms, sorting, data validation; COBOL is taught.

course35.prereq: Permission of instructor. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 cr hrs or 10 completions.
course35.topic: Planning, conducting, and reporting a special study appropriate to the needs of the students
course35.name: Individual Studies in Computer Science and Engineering
course35.desc: Planning, conducting, and reporting a special study appropriate to the needs of the students.

course36.prereq: 2221 or 222. Concur: 2231 or 321. Not open to students with credit for 2421
course36.topic: C pointers and memory (de)allocation, Transitioning to C, Basic C syntax, working in Unix, programming dynamic data structures with C, String manipulation and I/O in C, function pointers, command line argument passing, debugging, bit operations
course36.name: Advanced C Programming
course36.desc: Advanced C features for students with significant programming experience in another language.

course37.prereq: 2122, 2123, or 2231; and Gen Ed Writing: Level 2; and enrollment in CSE or CIS major, or Information Security minor. Not open to students with credit for 5501.
course37.topic: Professional ethics, Effective communication, Privacy / Civil liberties, Security / Civil liberties, Intellectual property, Computer risks, Computer crime
course37.name: Social, Ethical, and Professional Issues in Computing
course37.desc: Social, ethical, and professional issues facing computing professionals; ethical principles; discussion of case studies.

course38.prereq: 3901 or 3902 or 3903. Not open to students with credit for 5231 (757).
course38.topic: Characteristics of enterprise softw. sys, Software engineering process, Architecting softw. intensive sys, Software project management, Software design, Deployment, Maintenance and Management
course38.name: Software Engineering Techniques
course38.desc: Software engineering issues, techniques, methodologies and technologies; software lifecycle activities: requirements analysis, architecture, design, testing, deployment, maintenance; project management; enterprise software systems; frameworks.

course39.prereq: 3241, 3901, 3902, 3903, or 5241; and enrollment in CIS, CSE, ECE, or Business Info Sys major. Not open to students with credit for 5232.
course39.topic: Teamwork and organizational dynamics, Data flow diagramming, Requirements elicitation, UML, Software engineering, software development life cycle
course39.name: Software Requirements Analysis
course39.desc: Information systems analysis; object-oriented analysis models and tools; use cases, system modeling using UML; requirements specification development; term project.

course40.prereq: 2133 or 2231; and 2321 or Math 2366; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ISE, Data Analytics, ECE, Engr Physics, or Business Info Sys major, or CIS minor. Not open to students with credit for 5241.
course40.topic: Entity-Relationship (ER) Model, The Structure of the Relational Data Model, Relational Algebra and Relational Calculus, Functional Dependencies and Normalization, ER-to-Relational Data Model, SQL, Graphical User Interfaces, Embedded SQL, Object Relational Databases, XML,Active Databases
course40.name: Introduction to Database Systems
course40.desc: Database systems use, logical design, entity-relationship model, normalization, query languages and SQL, relational algebra and calculus, object relational databases, XML, active databases; database design project.

course41.prereq: 3241 or 5241; and 2421 or 3430; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, or Data Analytics major.
course41.topic: Indexing and Optimization, Data warehousing and OLAP, Cloud computing principles, Replication and partitioning strategies, Algorithms and platforms for cloud
course41.name: Data Management in the Cloud
course41.desc: Systematic organization of data on cloud computing architectures; basic indexing techniques, including B-tree and hash-based indexing; fundamentals of query optimization, including access path selection and cardinality estimation; full and partial replication; data partitioning and distributed task scheduling.

course42.prereq: 2231, 2421, 2331, and Math 3345; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, or Math major. Not open to students with credit for 5321.
course42.topic: Formal languages, Regular languages and finite automata, Grammars, Context-free languages and pushdown automata, Recursively enumerable languages and Turing machines
course42.name: Automata and Formal Languages
course42.desc: Machine-based and grammatical models of computation; finite automata and regular languages, pushdown automata and context-free languages, Turing machines; non-determinism; Church's Thesis.

course43.prereq: 2231, 2331 (680), and 2421, and 3901 (560), 3902, or 3903. Not open to students with credit for 5341 (655).
course43.topic: Overview of types of languages, Grammars , abstract & concrete parse tree, recursive descent parsing, Recursive descent interpretation, compilation, Principles of OO languages, Functional programming principles
course43.name: Principles of Programming Languages
course43.desc: Formal languages and grammars; recursive descent parsing; data types, expressions, control structures, parameter passing; compilers and interpreters; memory management; functional programming principles.

course44.prereq: 2231, and 2421 or ECE 2560, and 2000 or 2060; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, or ECE major. Not open to students with credit for 5421.
course44.topic: State of the art in computer architecture, Moore's law, Quantifying performance and power tradeoffs, Design of instruction set architectures, Digital logic and circuit design, Architecture and design of memory, Design of integer arithmetic logic unit, Processor design: non-pipelined and pipelined, Multicores, multiprocessors, interconnects, I/O subsystems
course44.name: Introduction to Computer Architecture
course44.desc: Organization of hardware and software in modern computer systems, including instruction set design, processor control, ALU design, pipelining, multicores and accelerators, and memory subsystem design.

course45.prereq: 2421; or 3430; or 2451 and ECE 2560; and enrollment in CIS, CSE, ECE, Engr Physics, or Data Analytics major. Prereq or concur: 2431 or 3430. Not open to students with credit for 5461.
course45.topic: Internet, TCP, IP layers, Internet data link and physical layers, Wireless networks, Network security
course45.name: Computer Networking and Internet Technologies
course45.desc: Computer networks, communication protocols, Internet TCP/IP and applications, wireless communications and network security.

course46.prereq: 2331 or 5331; and Math 2174 or 2568 or 4568 or 5520H; and Stat 3201 or 3450 or 3460 or 3470 or 4201 or Math 4530 or 5530H; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE or Data Analytics major. Not open to students with credit for 5521.
course46.topic: Basic representation and problem solving methods, Search techniques and game playing, Knowledge representation using logiC, Machine learning, probabilistic inference, Planning and common sense reasoning, Perception and communication
course46.name: Survey of Artificial Intelligence I: Basic Techniques
course46.desc: Survey of basic concepts and techniques in artificial intelligence, including problem solving, knowledge representation, and machine learning.

course47.prereq: 3901, 3902, or 3903; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, Music (BS), or ECE major. Not open to students with credit for 5541.
course47.name: Computer Game and Animation Techniques
course47.desc: Fundamental algorithms and mathematics in production of computer animation and video games, emphasizing control and rendering of animated characters.

course48.prereq: 2231; and 2321; and 2421 or 3430, or 2451 and ECE 2560; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, or Data Analytics major.
course48.topic: Dynamic web application, development and formatting of static web content, SQL, Be exposed to the use of application frameworks for the deployment of web applications, Be exposed to some basic security vulnerabilities sometimes found in web applications. Be exposed to methods for internationalizing web applications.
course48.name: Project: Design, Development, and Documentation of Web Applications
course48.desc: Intensive group project involving design, development, and documentation of a web application; client-side and server-side scripting; communication skills emphasized; builds programming maturity.

course49.prereq: 2231; and 2321; and 2421 or 3430, or 2451 and ECE 2560; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, Music (BS), or Data Analytics major.
course49.topic: 2D graphics objects and rendering, event based programming, elements of game engines such as AI, animation, memory management, and user control, game content creation and editing tools, writing, organizational, and communication skills, analyzing the intended audience for a written document and writing an audience profile, tradeoffs
course49.name: Project: Design, Development, and Documentation of Interactive Systems
course49.desc: Intensive group project involving design, development, and documentation of an interactive software system, a 2D interactive game; communication skills emphasized; builds programming maturity.

course50.prereq: 2231; and 2321; and 2421 or 3430, or 2451 and ECE 2560; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, or Data Analytics major.
course50.name: Project: Design, Development, and Documentation of System Software
course50.desc: Intensive group project involving design, development, and documentation of system software including an assembler and a linking loader; communication skills emphasized; builds programming maturity.

course51.name: Individual Studies in Computer Science and Engineering
course51.desc: Designed to give the student an opportunity to pursue special studies not otherwise offered.

course52.prereq: 2122, 2123, or 2231; and 2321; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, Engr Physics, or Data Analytics major, or CIS minor.
course52.topic: C Shell, C Shell programming, Regular expression in UNIX, Make, sed, awk
course52.name: The UNIX Programming Environment
course52.desc: Introduction to the UNIX programming environment including: shell programming (csh); regular expressions; makefiles; grep, sed, and awk programming languages.

course53.prereq: 2123 or 2231; and 2321; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, Engr Physics, or Data Analytics major, or CIS minor.
course53.topic: Compiling and running C++ programs, Overview of simple types in C++, Distinction between objects and classes, Compile-time picture vs. runtime, Stack vs. heap objects, Inheritance, Overriding, Virtual methods, Abstract class, Exceptions, Namespaces, Templates
course53.name: Programming in C++
course53.desc: Syntax and pragmatics of C++ programming; C++ types, arrays, classes, pointers; objects and classes; compile-time vs. run-time picture; inheritance; template classes.

course54.prereq: 2122, 2123, or 2231; and 2321; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, Engr Physics, or Data Analytics major, or CIS minor.
course54.topic: C# language basics, C# Generics and generic collection classes in .Net, Enumerations and Iterators, Delegates and Events, Equality, Anonymous types, Lambda Expressions, LINQ and functional programming in C#
course54.name: Programming in C#
course54.desc: C# programming for students well-versed in programming with another object-oriented language.

course55.prereq: 2122, 2123, or 2231; and 2321; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, Engr Physics, or Data Analytics major, or CIS minor.
course55.topic: Data structures, Program control and structure, Functions, I/O and symbols, Numbers and macros, Advanced topics
course55.name: Programming in Lisp
course55.desc: Lisp programming for students well-versed in programming with another language.

course56.prereq: 2122, 2123, or 2231; and 2321; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, Engr Physics, or Data Analytics major, or CIS minor.
course56.topic: Fundamental Python classes and functions, Object-oriented Programming in Python, Applications of graph theory, Design Patterns, Text processing and regular expressions, Functional Programming, Python library
course56.name: Programming in Python
course56.desc: Python programming for students well-versed in programming with another imperative language.

course57.prereq: 2231 and 2321; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, or Data Analytics major, or Information Security or CIS minor.
course57.topic: Information security, Legal regulatory issues, Risk management, Firewalls, Intrusion detection, Incident response, Cryptography, Access control
course57.name: Information Security
course57.desc: Introduction to security of digital information; threats and attacks; regulations; risk management; attack detection and response; cryptography; forensics; technical training and certifications.

course58.prereq: Permission of instructor. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 cr hrs or 10 completions.
course58.name: Undergraduate Research in Computer Science and Engineering
course58.desc: Opportunity for undergraduate student to conduct research in Computer Science and Engineering.

course59.prereq: Permission of instructor. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 cr hrs or 10 completions.
course59.name: Computer Science and Engineering Research for Thesis
course59.desc: Supervised research and project work arranged individually.

course60.prereq: 2431 or 5431 (660). Not open to students with credit for 769.
course60.topic: Introduction to Distributed Enterprise Systems, Overview of the technologies used for distributed enterprise systems, XML, Javascript, AJAX and JSON, Object-relational mapping (ORM), Enterprise Java, Designing enterprise applications, SOAP and REST Web Services, Enterprise integration via the Enterprise Service Bus, Cloud computing toolkits, Mobile and edge computing, High-volume computing on mainframe computers
course60.name: Distributed Enterprise Computing
course60.desc: Current application and middleware frameworks for distributed enterprise computing; XML; Enterprise Java; SOAP and REST web services; AJAX and JSON; enterprise service bus; Hadoop; mobile computing.

course61.topic: Introduction to vocabulary HCI, business processes, supply chains, enterprise architectures and systems, and symbiotic computing; declarative modeling and analysis methods using case studies. Use of performance linkages between services in-the-large and in-the-small, for service level and policy formulation,and evaluation; service life-cycle. Patterns and principles for co-engineering Adaptive Complex systems to achieve behaviors
course61.name: Applied Enterprise Architectures and Services
course61.desc: Modeling/analysis of complex enterprise architectures; enterprise patterns (workflow, broker, warehousing); methods for service performance (lean, ontologies, data mining, etc.); emerging topics in semantic cyber-infrastructures, social computation

course62.topic: Characteristics of mobile applications, History of mobile application frameworks, Overview of mobile application development languages, Application models of mobile application frameworks, User-interface design for mobile applications, Managing application data, Integrating with cloud services, Creating enriched user interfaces. Multi-touch and gesture-based application, Integrating networking, the OS and hardware into mobile applications
course62.name: Mobile Application Development
course62.desc: Mobile application development frameworks; Architecture, design and engineering issues, techniques, methodologies for mobile application development.

course64.topic: Transaction Management, Query Processing and Optimization, Advanced Indexing and Query Processing, Multi-dimensional Index Structures.Data Warehouse Design and Implementation, New Topics and Applications
course64.name: Advanced Database Management Systems
course64.desc: Transaction management; query processing and optimization; organization of database systems, advanced indexing, multi-dimensional data, similarity-based analysis, performance evaluation, new database applications.

course65.prereq: 3241 or 5241; and 2331, 5331, Stat 3301, or ISE 3200; and enrollment in CSE, CIS, ECE, Data Analytics, or ISE major.
course65.track: Computer Systems (CSY), Database Systems and Data Analytics (DBA),
course65.topic: Knowledge Discovery Process and Background, Elements of Data Preprocessing and Data Transformations, Data Clustering, Data Classification, Frequent Pattern Mining, Analyzing Graphs and Networks, Anomaly Detection, Applications (Bioinformatics, Social Networks)
course65.name: Introduction to Data Mining
course65.desc: Knowledge discovery, data mining, data preprocessing, data transformations; clustering, classification, frequent pattern mining, anomaly detection, graph and network analysis; applications.

course66.topic: Motivation and Introduction to Basic Concepts, Graph Algorithms, Page Rank and Community Discovery, Network Models, The Web and Social Network Analysis: Putting It All Together,
course66.name: Introduction to Network Science
course66.desc: Introduction to Network Science; Global and Local Network Measures; PageRank; Community Discovery Algorithms; Network Models; Understanding the role of network analysis in Web and Social network applications.

course67.prereq: 3901 (560), 3902, or 3903, and 3341 (655). Not open to students with credit for 756.
course67.topic: Compiler structure, Lexical analysis, Parsing, Type checking, Intermediate code, Control-flow analysis, Dataflow analysis, Code optimizations, Generation of machine code, Parallelism and locality, Instruction scheduling, Register allocation
course67.name: Compiler Design and Implementation
course67.desc: Lexical and syntax analysis using compiler generation tools; type checking; intermediate code; control-flow analysis; dataflow analysis; code optimizations; code generation; compiler project.

course68.prereq: 2331 (680), 5331, Math 4573 (573), or 4580 (580), and Stat 3460 (427) or 3470. Not open to students with credit for 723 or 794Q.
course68.name: Introduction to Cryptography
course68.desc: Foundations of cryptography; mathematical formulations/proofs of security goals; theory and practical constructions of encryption schemes, MACs, digital signatures; zero-knowledge proof systems; cryptographic protocols.

course69.topic: Mobile handset, Mobile handset processor architecture; memory systems; I/O devices and sensors, Virtual machine; system power management, Mobile social networking; security
course69.name: Mobile Handset Systems and Networking
course69.desc: Mobile handset architecture: processors, memory, I/O devices, sensors, virtual machine and power management; different ranges of wireless communication technologies; TCP/IP over wireless; mobile social networking.

course70.prereq: 2431 or 5431. Not open to students with credit for 662.
course70.topic: Linux basics, Internals of system calls, Linux CPU scheduling and process management, Linux interrupt handling, Linux memory management, Linux file systems
course70.name: Operating Systems Laboratory
course70.desc: Introduction to the internals of operating systems; designing and implementing components within commercial operating systems: system calls, CPU scheduling, context switching, process management, memory management, file systems.

course71.prereq: 2431 (660) or 5431. Not open to students with credit for 741.
course71.topic: Fundamentals, Process management, Processor scheduling, File management, Performance management. The assembled package.
course71.name: Comparative Operating Systems
course71.desc: A careful examination of a number of representative computer operating systems.

course72.topic: Fundamental performance issues, Cache and its impact on performance, Loop Transformations for performance enhancement, Data dependence analysis, Overview of parallel architectures and programming models, Shared-memory parallel programming, Message passing, Programming GPUs, Programming for high performance with short-vector SIMD instruction sets.
course72.name: Introduction to Parallel Computing
course72.desc: Parallel programming models; sequential and parallel performance issues; high-performance computer architecture; design, analysis, implementation and performance evaluation of parallel algorithms.

course73.topic: Review of C pointers and memory allocation/deallocation, Review of the Unix environment, NesC, Communication using UDP sockets, Communication using TCP sockets
course73.name: Network Programming
course73.desc: IP-based socket programming in C/C++, TinyOS programming in NesC.

course74.prereq: 3461, 5461, or ECE 3561; or Grad standing in Engineering or Math and Physical Sciences. Cross-listed in ECE 5101.
course74.topic: Historical Milestones and Current Wireless Networks, Understanding the Wireless Communication Channel, Multiple Access Techniques (FDMA, TDMA, CDMA), Power Control, Proactive and Reactive Routing, Congestion control, System case studies (802.11, Bluetooth, etc.), Energy management in sensor networks
course74.name: Introduction to Wireless Networking
course74.desc: Fundamental concepts in cellular design, Wireless-LANs, MANETs, and sensor networks will be explored. Specific topics will include propagation, fading, cellular-design, power-management, routing, scheduling, and control.

course75.prereq: Jr, Sr, or Grad standing, or permission of instructor. Not open to students with credit for ECE 5561. Cross-listed in ECE 5561.
course75.topic: Basic concepts and definitions, Data Security, Software security, Component security, Connection security, System security, Human security, Organizational security, Social Security
course75.name: Introduction to Cybersecurity
course75.desc: Introduction to cybersecurity. Technical fundamentals of data, software, component, network, and system security. Cybersecurity from an organizational and societal view point, including human factors.

course76.prereq: 3901, 3902, or 3903, and 3461, 5461, or 4471; or Grad standing.
course76.track: Information and Computation Assurance (ICA), Computer Networking (CNT)
course76.topic: Host hardening, Network Security, Computer Investigations, Miscellaneous topics relating to information security, VMware, project objectives
course76.name: Information Security Projects
course76.desc: Team-based projects: solve information security problems (mobile/static host/network hardening, intrusion detection and vulnerability scanning, forensics); results communicated through report writing and presentation.

course77.prereq: 3461 (677) or 5461. Not open to students with credit for 651.
course77.track: Information and Computation Assurance (ICA), Computer Networking (CNT)
course77.topic: Security threats and services, Elements of cryptography, Protocols for security services, Network and internet security, Advanced security issues and technologies.
course77.name: Network Security
course77.desc: Security threats and services, elements of cryptography, protocols for security services, network and internet security, advanced security issues and technologies.

course78.topic: Secure software principles and practice, Memory safety, memory corruption & vulnerabilities, Vulnerability identification, Exploit development, Defenses.
course78.name: Software Security
course78.desc: Software security fundamentals, secure coding principles and practices, common software vulnerabilities, memory exploits (shell code), vulnerability analysis (e.g., reverse engineering, fuzzing and symbolic execution), and defenses against common vulnerability exploitation.

course79.prereq: 2431, 5431, or Grad standing. Not open to students with credit for ECE 5567.01. Cross-listed in ECE 5567.01.
course79.topic: Common reconnaissance, Confidentiality attack: side-channel attacks, Confidentiality attack: crypto and password attacks, Confidentiality attack: data leakage attacks, Integrity attacks: malware attacks, Integrity attacks: control flow hijack attacks, Availability attacks, Human weakness attack.
course79.name: Offensive Security
course79.desc: This course will give students an overview of existing offensive computing techniques, which include well known attacks that break confidentiality, integrity and availability of computing resources. Attacks targeting on human weaknesses without taking special care to security will also be discussed.

course80.prereq: 2431, 5431, or Grad standing. Prereq or concur: 5471 or ECE 5561. Not open to students with credit for ECE 5567.02. Cross-listed in ECE 5567.02.
course80.topic: Reverse engineering tools, Taxonomy of malware, Static analysis techniques, Static analysis techniques, Dynamic analysis techniques: tainting, Dynamic analysis techniques: fuzzing, Dynamic analysis techniques, Introduction to anti-static analysis techniques, Introduction to anti-dynamic analysis techniques, Machine Learning security, Video Game Security, AI for malware analysis.
course80.name: Reverse Engineering and Malware Analysis
course80.desc: This course will give students an overview of cutting edge reverse engineering techniques as well as software security and defense practices. Programming experience in C required.

course81.prereq: 3901 (560) or 3902 or 3903, and Math 2568 (568) or 571. Not open to students with credit for 781.
course81.topic: Overview of graphics APIs, Overview of graphics hardware, Coordinate systems in rendering pipeline, Modeling transformation, 3D viewing, Basic lighting algorithms, Introduction to OpenGL Shading Language, OpenGL, Real time shadow algorithms, Bump mapping, Environment mapping, Advanced texture mapping and anti-aliasing, Advanced shading and lighting algorithms
course81.name: Real-Time Rendering
course81.desc: Comprehensive list of topics in real-time rendering using OpenGL and GLSL, including coordinate systems, transformations, viewing, illumination, texture mapping, and shader-based algorithms.

course82.prereq: Math 2568 (568) or 571. Not open to students with credit for 784.
course82.topic: Curve modeling (B-splines and Bezier), Subdivision curves, Surface geometry and topology, Surface modeling (B-splines and Bezier), Subdivision surfaces, B-rep, CSG, Boolean operations, Curve and surface reconstruction, Surface and volume simplification, Mesh generation, Parameterization.
course82.name: Geometric Modeling
course82.desc: Common algorithmic and mathematical techniques for modeling geometric objects in computer graphics and CAD applications; sample based modeling, mesh generation, and hierarchical representations.

course83.prereq: 5361, Stat 3301, 3541, or 5541. Not open to students with credit for 694L
course83.topic: Historical remarks, Abstract visualization concepts and the visualization pipeline, Principles of visual design, Basic mapping concepts, Perception and color theory, Visualization of matrices, graphs and trees, Visualization of high-dimensional data and demensionality reduction techniques, Visualization of scalar fieldsVisualization of vector fields, Evaluation and Interaction models
course83.name: Introduction to Data Visualization
course83.desc: Principles and methods for visualizing data from measurements and calculations in physical and life sciences, and transactional and social disciplines; information visualization; scientific visualization.

course84.prereq: 3541 or 5541 or 581. Not open to students with credit for 782.
course84.topic: Introduction to Realistic Rendering and Literate Programming, Geometry, Transformations, Shapes, Acceleration Structures, Color and Radiometry, Sampling and Reconstruction, Reflection Models, Texture, Volume Rendering and Scattering, Monte Carlo Methods, Unbiased Light Transport.
course84.name: Advanced Computer Graphics
course84.desc: Advanced topics in computer graphics; image synthesis, lighting and rendering, sampling and material properties, volume rendering.

course85.topic: Background in virtual reality and virtual environments, Input devices: Wands, 3D mouse, Immersion and presence: Stereo, head-tracking, Real-time graphics: Rendering and visualization, Augmented and mixed reality, Navigation: Travel and way finding in 3D, Selection and manipulation of objects in 3D, System control: Change of system state in 3D, The future of VE.
course85.name: Virtual Reality
course85.desc: Principles and methods for the design, development, and evaluation of three-dimensional interfaces in virtual environments and their applications in data science, medicine, and engineering.

course86.prereq: Philos 1338 or CSE 2501, and 3901 or 3902 or 3903; or Grad standing; or permission of instructor.
course86.topic: Trade secrets, Patents, Copyrights, Trademarks, Designs.
course86.name: Legal Topics for Computer Engineers
course86.desc: This course introduces students to areas of law that govern computer engineering and design. The goals of the course include mastery of a set of legal doctrines, as well as immersion in the legal method used by lawyers to analyze problems and by judges to decide cases. Students can expect to learn how to evaluate computer engineering methods and projects through the lens of legal analysis.

course87.prereq: Permission of instructor. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 cr hrs. Cross-listed in Ling, Philos, Psych, and SphHrng.
course87.topic: Interdisciplinary field of Cognitive Science, Fundamental issues of each discipline, Illustrations of representative research being conducted at OSU.
course87.name: Proseminar in Cognitive Science
course87.desc: Provides an in-depth examination of cognitive science from an interdisciplinary perspective.
